p.seg: DEPARTMENT OF LABOR of the State of Nebraska For Two Years 'Ending December 31, 1927 Adam McMullen, Governor mm & §

LETTER OF TRAXSMITTAL Lincoln, Nebraska, July 1, 1928. To His Excellency, Adam McMullen, Governor of Nebraska: In compliance with the laws of the State of Nebraska I have the honor to submit herewith the official report of the Department of Labor for the years 1926 and 1927. Respectfully, FRANK A. KENNEDY. Secretary of Labor and Compensation Commissioner.

Secretary of Labor Prank A. Kennedy Chief of Bureau of Compensation J. H. Jeffrey Assistant Commissioner, Omaha Office John Larsen Special Investigator _ O. M. Olsen Record Clerk Carrie Kennedy Stenographer _ Doris King

6 HISTORICAL The Labor Department of Nebraska was created in 1887 as the Bureau of Labor Census and Industrial Statistics. For 30 years the Bureau functioned primarily and almost solely as a gatherer and disseminator of statistics. However, in 1917 the administration of the Workmen's Compensation Law was vested in the Bureau, and since that time it has taken its place as one of the important departmental agencies of the state government. A Deputy Com- missioner of Labor, appointed by the governor, administered the affairs of the Bureau of Labor until 1919, when the Department of Labor was created under the Civil Administrative Code Law, and the title of Secretary of Labor conferred upon its chief official. The names of the heads of the department and the years of their service are as follows: John Jenkins 1887-1888 John Jenkins 1889-1890 Phillip Andres 1891-1892 J. B. Erion 1893-1894 J. H. Powers ,. 18 95-1896 Sidney J. Kent.... 189 7-1898 Sidney J. Kent _ 1899-1900 C. E. Watson 1901-19 Burrett Bush 190 3-190 4 Burrett Bush 1905-1906 John J. Ryder 1907-1908 W. M. Maupin 1909-19K L. V. Guye 1911-1912 C. W. Pool 19 13-1914 F. M. Coffey 1915-1916 G. E. Norman 1917-1918 Frank A. Kennedy 1919-192 0 Frank A. Kennedy 1921-1922 L. B. Frye 19 23-1924 Frank A. Kennedy 1925-192 6 •Frank A. Kennedy 192 7-19 2 8 Charles B. Pirie 1928 •Died August 13, 1928.

7 Important Compensation Legislation During the 1927 session of the legislature two important amendments to the compensation law were enacted. Both of these amendments were fathered by the Department of Labor. VOLUNTEER FIREMEN* For a number of years the department has recognized the in - justice of expecting members of Volunteer Fire Departments In the various cities and towns of the state to risk life and limb protecting the property of the citizenship, without themselves in turn being protected in the event of an accident while in the performance of this duty. At the 1926 session of the Nebraska Volunteer Firemen's Association resolutions were adopted favor - ing an amendment to the compensation law to include volunteer firemen in the list of employees protected by the law. At that time Senator J. C. McGowan of Norfolk was president of that association. He was the author of the bill in the senate, and his untiring zeal in support of it entitles him to much credit for its enactment into law. In a word the amendment provides that any volunteer fireman, while on duty, shall receive the same protection and mefits from the city or village, as is given to any other employee in the state. FARM LABOR The second amendment to the law simplifies the manner in which those employers who are specifically excluded may elect to be bound by the provisions of the law. They could formerly elect to come under the provisions of the law by purchasing a policy of compensation insurance and filing a joint election, signed by them - selves and their employees, with this Department. For more than ten years quite a number of farmers and ranchers purchased the insurance to protect themselves and their employees, but in many instances failed to complete the transaction insofar as filing an elec - tion with the Department was concerned. They did not know that step was necessary. During 1926 four very serious accidents occurred to employees of farmers and ranchers, and in each in - stance the insurance companies bitterly contested the cases, re - fusing to admit liability because of the fact that the joint election had not been filed. All four of these cases went to the Supreme Court and were won by the insurance companies on this technicality. From then on the Department redoubled its efforts, with the re - sult that the legislature passed an amendment that left the status

8 of the farmer today the same as it was prior to this amendment, and simply eliminated the "red tape" incident to filing the election. tAny farmer desiring to come under the law may now do so ply by purchasing a policy of compensation insurance, and possession by him of such a policy "at the time of an accident iny of his employees shall be conclusive proof" of his election :ome under the law. RESOLUTION The 1927 session of the legislature, by resolution, empowered and requested the Governor to appoint a commission to investigate the operation and application of the Nebraska Workmen's Com - pensation law, and to report its findings and proposed amend - ments, if any, to the Governor not later than December 1, 1928. As a reason for its adoption the resolution says: "During each succeeding session of the legislature there are quite a few bills Introduced having for their purpose the amendment of the com - pensation law; these amendments are of a varied nature, some of them broadening the provisions of the law and some of them limit- Ing the operation and application of the law, while other amend - ments offered would largely destroy the controlling intent and purpose in the passage of the compensation law." Kae resolution provided that the commission be composed of members; two employers, two employees and three rep - tatives of the general public, and in compliance with the ition, the Governor has appointed the following men to serve imbers of the Commission: F. A. Good, Lincoln, chairman; Walton B. Roberts, Lincoln, vice-chairman; E. Glen Callen, Lincoln, secretary Theodore Jensen, Omaha; Fred A. Eissler, Lincoln; Clyde B. Dempster, Beatrice H. G. Hoertier, Omaha. I'erhaps no better group of men could have been selected to irm this arduous though highly important task, and the peo - jf Nebraska may rest assured that the report submitted to Governor will reflect credit upon him and each individual ber of the Commission, and be of great and lasting benefit le state.

9 Bureau of Compensation The Workmen's Compensation Law of Nebraska was enacted by the legislature of 1913; was held up by the referendum and became a law December 1, 1914. The following table shows the number of accidents, medical and hospital expense, and the amount of compensation paid to injured workers each year for the thirteen years the law has been in force, from 1915 to 1927, inclusive, as reported to the Com - pensation Commissioner. These totals include not alone the money paid out by insurance companies, but also that paid by those large employers who have elected to carry their own insurance. 10 TWENTY-FIRST BIENNIAL REPORT Statistical Report- 1926 More accidents are reported to the Commission each succeed- ing year. This is, of course, largely attributable to the natural and normal growth of industry. In addition, as the beneficent provisions of the law become more widely known, it is inevitable that more and more injured workmen will inquire regarding their rights under the law. 20 LUMP SUM SETTLEMENTS In the 1925 report of the Department, under the heading of "Evil of Lump Sum Settlements," it was stated that the Nebraska law provided that the Commissioner's approval was a requisite to lump-sum settlements and that the reasons for refusing to ap - prove such settlements in a great majority of the applications was that the practice was against public policy and rarely for the best interests of the injured workers, and their dependents. This theory is universally recognized as fundamental in best admin - istration of workmen's compensation acts. In July, 1!»27, our Supreme Court in the case of Jackson vs. Ford Motor Company, 115 Nebraska, page 758, decided, in ell that the Commissioner's approval of a lump sum settlement was not essential, before a judgment could be entered relieving the employer (or insurance company) of further liability. During the six months of the year following this decision the Commissioner approved only twelve lump-sum settlements, in - volving $21,316.30. During that same period twenty other lump-sum settlements were ordered paid by the District Court, involving $29,608.85. Most of these applications were disapproved by the Commissioner, Sut in a few instances the order was entered without the applica - tion even being submitted to the Commissioner. This procedure is in direct violation of the requirement of the law. as laid down t>y our Supreme Court in the Jackson case cited above. The lump-sum settlement problem has been recognized sufficient importance by the reecntly appointed Commission to in - vestigate the compensation law, that a sub-committee to study the subject has been selected. .MALE AND FEMALE Accidents to 17,822 men, and to 1,232 women were reported to the Department during the year 1927. Accidents to married men reported were 10,946, and to single men 6,125. In 751 cases the status of the injured employe was not given. Of the 1,232 accidents to women reported to the Department, 502 were married, while 662 were single, and the status was not given in 68 cases. If these reports reflect the status of women in industry in this state, then over 40 per cent of the employed women

23 CLOSED CASES The following table reflects the business of various employers who have been licensed to carry their own insurance, in those cases that originated during 1927 and were also closed during the year From the foregoing tables it will be seen that, if we take only the 18,090 cases that originated and were closed during the year, the medical expense of $238,365.69 exceeds the compensation paid of $210,903.50, by $27,459.69. MEDICAL AND HOSPITAL EXPENSES RLecognizing the seriousness of the ever-increasing medical and ital expenses, the Department in this report presents compre - hensive analyses of this important subject. Rrhe total cost for medical and hospital expense of $300,390.24, hown in this report for the year 1927, does not represent the actual expenditures for this service. A considerable sum in addi - tion was spent by employers and insurance companies, but was not reported to the Department by them. No elaboration of the subjoined tables will be attempted. They were compiled and are published for whatever of value they may be to the employers of the state. EXCEPTIONAL MEDICAL EXPENSE During the year 341 cases were reported in which the medical expense exceeded $100.00. In 262 of these cases the medical ex - pense was from $100.00 to $200.00 or a total of $37,031.62. In these 262 cases the compensation paid amounted to $37,917.12. In 73 cases the medical expense was from $200.00 to $500.00 or a total of $20,810.73, while the compensation in these 73 cases amounted to $27,818.72. In six cases the medical expense exceeded $500.00 or a total of $4,167.48. Compensation in these 6 cases amounted to $5,907.04. Thus, in these 341 cases, the medical expenses total $62,009.83 while the compensation was $71,642.88. Ninety-five of these cases were hernia, in which the medical expense was $14,902.37. Forty of them were strains, fractures and dislocation of the lower extremities, wherein the medical expense amounted to $10,224.31; while 21 were fractures of the upper extremities in - volving a medical expense of $3,598.49. Twenty-seven were cuts and bruises to the lower extremities costing $4,185.38; while 20 were cuts and bruises to the upper extremities wherein the medical expense was $2,674.15. Infections of the upper extremities numbered 11 or a total medical expense of $2,647.61; while in 6 cases infection of the lower extremities cost $1,496.98. Twenty-five sprained backs entailed a medical expense of $4,404.38; while five foreign bodies in the eye cost $1,016.20. CAUSES OF ACCIDENTS What is your guess as to the cause of the greatest number of accidents to workmen? No, you are wrong; guess again. From the complaints of insurance adjusters, one would be led to believe that herniae were occurring by the thousands, y.i out of the 19,000 accidents reported only 161 such cases were among them. Of these 161 cases the record shows that in 95 of them medical expense ran over the $100.00 mark for a total of $14.902..">7, while the compensation paid was $9,479.26, or almost exactly $100.00 each. By the law averages, then, actually only in 112 out of the 1G1 hernia cases was medical and hospital ex- penses and compensation paid Almost everybody would say without hesitation that lacerated lingers was the most common cause of injuries sure, there were 2,104 such accidents, involving a medical of $19,210.16 and payments of compensation amounting 758.51. But, to our amazement, the cause of the t of accidents was our old friend, foreign body in accounted for 2,331 accidents, although the medical exp considerably less than that for the cut fingers, being $1 while the compensation payments for th to $3, 993. IS. Some people seem to think that building nails more often than there are either nails o state. As a matter of fact, only 129 accidents Bi of all kinds in the foot to all classes and kinds of emploi ling eight women, were reported to the Department, and se involved was negligible. Sprained backs are the cause of more worry to both the De - partment and the insurance companies than any other class of in - juries. It is but natural, then, that we .should get in the mental attitude of believing that they constituted about 5o r r of all acci - dents, and we were relieved to find that only 'J*2 men and 35 women were disabled from this cause. The medical expense in these 1,017 cases amounted to $13,319.63, while a total of $13,146.64 was paid as compensation. Kotwithstanding the efforts of employers and insurance com - s to get the injured employee to the doctor immediately the accident, the outstanding fact is that in 1,159 cases in - in developed. Finger infections number 517, while in 300

27 Eistances the hand was involved. These infections cost over $30, - 00.00, of which amount $17,142.26 was expended for medical •eatment while $13,039.03 was paid in compensation. This is the first time the Department has ever attempted an analysis of the nature and location of injuries as contained in he following tables. While they are not as extensive as we should ike to make them, still we believe that a careful study of them will be of great interest to employers and employees in general, and particularly to the members of Safety First organizations. 83 Little Violations — Big Judgments Because of the fact that this Report is mailed to more than 3,000 employers in Nebraska, most of whom have never before had an opportunity to acquaint themselves with the information given below, we take the liberty of re-printing, with the necessary changes to bring it down to date, the following from the 1925 N'pbraska has one of the very best child labor laws in the United States. We venture the assertion that it is more rigidly enforced than is that perhaps of any other state. Violations of our child labor legislation have been reduced since 1919-1920 until today they are practically nil. Several factors are responsible for this very satisfactory con - dition, the predominant and outstanding one of which is the inter - pretation of the provisions of our Workmen's Compensation Law by our Supreme Court in every instance where the question has The gist of these decisions is that the illegal employment of a child nullifies the policy of compensation insurance, leaving the employer without that protection and subjecting him to suit under the common law with the consequent heavy damages usually imposed. In the few instances where violations of the law were found a warning to the employer was all that was necessary to bring about the desired result. During the years 1926 and 1927 a total of 686 "Age and Schooling Permits" were filed with the Department, 305 being received during 1926, and 381 during 1927. Of these permits 431 were issued to boys and girls in Omaha, 143 in Lincoln, and 112 out-state. Between the ages of 14 and 15 years, 153 permits were issued to boys, and 103 to girls, while between the ages of 15 and 16 years, 240 permits were issued to boys und 190 to girls, making a total of 393 issued to boys, and 293 to girls during the two year period. There has been a general tendency on the part of the employers of female and child labor to comply with the statutory regulations, and the Department experienced very little difficulty in their en - forcement. The American employer of today shows a greater inter - est in the welfare of his employees than the employer of former years. His attitude toward the beneficial labor laws is sympathetic rather than hostile. He is not the employer who persistently seeks to violate the female labor law.

84 DANGER TO EMPLOYER However, it will be of interest to some employers to know that the Standerd Workmen's Compensation Insurance policies provide that compensation will be paid only to "such of said employe** as art' legally employed." This means that the employers of children under 16 years of age employed at hazardous occupations, and female labor employed contrary to the provisions of the female labor law, are not protected by the Nebraska Workmen's Compensation Law. This department knows of two concrete cases wherein the em - ployers had to pay damages under common law because of the illegal employment of children under 16 years of age, injured in the course of their employment. In Fremont one case went to the jury and a judgment of $20,000 was returned against the employer, notwithstanding he carried com - pensation insurance. Later it was settled by the employer by cash payment of $12,000. The other case was at Wahoo where an employer had to pay $4,500 under common law because of the illegal employment of a boy under 16 years of age. (In another case in Lincoln, a jury in the District Court in 1927 ire a verdict of (8,000.00 tn a 14 year old girl who severely in - red her hand and was employed without a permit. The em - >yer's compensation insurance carrier would have nothing to do th the claim. In instructing the jury, the District Judge in effect d them that it was only a question of "how much". The case now pending in Supreme Court on appeal. I This same clause in the compensation insurance policies will ly to any employer who violates the female labor law. The wledge of these laws on the part of the employers of the state been a great aid to this department in their enforcement. Private Employment Agencies The Department of Labor is charged with the duty of licensing employment agencies in this state. It has been successful in secur- Kie applications of all the agencies operating, and in only one o instances was it necessary to threaten prosecution in order ure the annual license fee of $50.00 prescribed by the statute. Labels and Trade Marks The statute imposes on the Department of Labor the duty of registering labels, trade-marks, trade names, etc. It also authorizes the Secretary of State to issue certificates of registration in certain specified instances, thus dividing the activities and the records, and causing no little confusion. The law should be amended, giving to the Secretary of State authority to issue all certificates, thus placing the duty where, in our opinion, it rightfully belongs. During the year 1926, trade marks registered totaled 61, while in 1927, the Department issued 56 certificates of registration.

86 Rehabilitation of Industrially Disabled REPORT OP DEPARTMENT FOR VOCATIONAL. EDUCATION (Rehabilitation Division) B October 18, 1920, Governor S. R. McKelvle, by governor's mation, accepted the provisions of the Federal Rehabilitation which Nebraska became a partner to the federal government retraining and returning to remunerative employment those s who by reason of physical disability were unable to earn ihood. This action was upheld by the legislature during the ing session, making it effective July 1, 1921. Among the provisions of the federal act was one requiring that the Department of Vocational Education and of Labor and Com - pensation enter into a definite agreement whereby they would render mutual cooperation in the assistance of persons disabled by industrial accidents. This agreement was entered into on November 23, 1920, and bore the signature of John M. Matzen, Secretary of the State Board for Vocational Education; of Frank A. Kennedy, Secretary of the State Department of Labor, and of Governor S. R. McKelvie. The relationship between the two departments has become closer with the passing of the years and has resulted in enabling many workers disabled by industrial accidents to either readjust themselves to their old occupations or train themselves for some new vocation by which they might again take up their proper positions as productive members of society. Following is a brief summary of industrial accident cases on ch there was joint departmental action during the years 1926 1927: 1926 Dick Reese and George Cornelions made almost complete re - covery and returned to work. V. E. Dnnkin, though he lost a hand, was able to retain his former position. One person had a mental condition which made it impossible for this department to assist him. A. W. Merrick, Omaha, Nebraska — Disability: Pernicious anemia. Not a compensation case but reported by Commissioner. Was started In training in poultry raising but became physically unable to do anything. For the balance of the cases (8) reported to us during this year, the following detailed summaries are given: Clarence Davis, Maxwell, Nebraska — Disability: Loss of right hand, part of the figners of left hand, the use of one eye and in - juries to his leg and body. Mr. Davis also suffered severely from shock as a result of a dynamite explosion. Payment of com - pensation was contested and a long legal battle resulted in his favor. In the meantime, he is going ahead in an earnest and vigorous attempt to reestablish himself on a small farm near Maxwell. His determined fight to carry on has won for him the admiration and respect of all those who know him. This depart - ment is furnishing him a much needed artificial arm and double hook. Tiiul D. Cramer, Omaha, Nebraska — Disability: Partial loss of use of left limb. For eighteen years, this man was a buyer in the Union Stock Yards at Omaha. A kick on the knee resulted in in - fection which made it impossible for him to carry on in this line of work. He was given training in poultry raising by this de - partment at the College of Agriculture and is now the owner of a fine poultry farm on the outskirts of Omaha. Harvey Hamilton, Omaha, Nebraska — Disability: Serious injury to eyes. Mr. Hamilton was a fireman and was blinded by a flying piece of wood which struck him in the eye. He was given training in poultry raising on an employment training basis. With the aid of his able wife, he is getting started, near Omaha, on a poultry project which is proving quite profitable. Ktieodore Thomas, Omaha, Nebraska — Disability: Loss of •s of left hand. Was a mechanic in the mill room for Over- Trail Tire Company. Is now studying acetyline welding on an jyment training basis with the Omaha Welding Company, lgements for his training were made by this department. Stevens, Lincoln, Nebraska — Disability: Complete com - pound fracture of the limb which made it impossible for him to carry on as truck driver. Was given three months' special training at the College of Agriculture in dairy subject and is now a cow tester for the Douglas County Cow Testing Association. He was given employment training by this department in storage battery repair and auto electrical work and is now employed in this line of work In a Lincoln auto electric shop.
